claim: unless they retire , every incumbent north carolina us house representative be re - elect in 1822
resp:
<think>
Alright, I'm trying to figure out whether the claim is true or false based on the given HTML table. The claim says, "unless they retire, every incumbent North Carolina US House representative be re-elected in 1822." 

First, I need to understand what each part of the claim means. It's stating that unless these representatives retire, they will all get re-elected in 1822. So, I should check if all the incumbents listed in the table who were up for re-election in 1822 did so successfully.

Looking at the table, it has several rows for different districts: 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, and 10. Each row includes details like the incumbent's name, party, year first elected, result of the election, and the candidates.

I'll go through each row to see if the incumbents were re-elected in 1822 or retired. If all of them either retired or were re-elected, then the claim holds. Otherwise, it doesn't.

Starting with North Carolina 2: The incumbent is Hutchins G. Burton. His result is "re-elected." So he was re-elected, which aligns with the claim since he didn't retire.

Next, North Carolina 4: The incumbent is William S. Blackledge, and his result is "retired Democratic-Republican hold." Here, he retired, so according to the claim, if they don't retire, they get re-elected. Since he retired, it's acceptable under the claim.

Moving on to North Carolina 5: Incumbent Charles Hooks was "re-elected." So again, no retirement, and he was re-elected as per the claim.

North Carolina 6: Incumbent Weldon N. Edwards' result is "re-elected" with 100% support. No retirement here either, so it fits.

Now, North Carolina 7: The incumbent is Archibald McNeill, who ran under the Federalist party. His result is "retired Federalist hold." He retired, which again falls under the condition that if they don't retire, they get re-elected. Since he did retire, it's acceptable.

North Carolina 9: Incumbent Romulus M. Saunders was "re-elected," so no retirement here; he was re-elected as per the claim.

Lastly, North Carolina 10: Incumbent John Long was "re-elected" with 66.9% of the vote against John MacClelland. So again, no retirement, just a successful re-election.

Looking through all these, every incumbent either retired or was re-elected in 1822. There's no case where an incumbent didn't retire but failed to get re-elected. Therefore, the claim seems to hold true based on the table provided.
</think>
